Question: What is the primary purpose of the selection sort algorithm?
Option A: a. To search for a specific element in an array.
Option B: b. To arrange the elements of an array in a specific order.
Option C: c. To find the maximum or minimum element in an array.
Option D: d. To traverse an array in a circular manner.
Correct Option: b. To arrange the elements of an array in a specific order.

Question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of the insertion sort algorithm?
Option A: a. It uses a buffer to temporarily hold elements.
Option B: b. It uses recursion to sort the array.
Option C: c. It compares each element with the previous ones.
Option D: d. It is a divide-and-conquer algorithm.
Correct Option: c. It compares each element with the previous ones.

Question: What is the time complexity of the merge sort algorithm in the worst case?
Option A: a. O(n log n)
Option C: c. O(n)
Option D: d. O(log n)
Correct Option: a. O(n log n)

Question: How does the partition scheme in quicksort work?
Option A: a. It swaps the pivot element with the middle element of the array.
Option B: b. It partitions the array into two halves, one with elements less than the pivot and one with elements greater than the pivot.
Option C: c. It searches for the maximum element in the array and swaps it with the pivot.
Option D: d. It iteratively swaps the pivot element with each element in the array.
Correct Option: b. It partitions the array into two halves, one with elements less than the pivot and one with elements greater than the pivot.

Question: What is the main difference between the top-down and bottom-up merge sort algorithms?
Option A: a. The direction of the merge operation.
Option B: b. The way the pivot is chosen.
Option C: c. The use of recursion.
Option D: d. The way the array is divided.
Correct Option: a. The direction of the merge operation.

Question: What is the time complexity of Linear Search in the worst-case scenario?
Option A: a. O(log n)
Option B: b. O(n)
Correct Option: b. O(n)

Question: Which of the following is a prerequisite for performing a Binary Search on an array?
Option A: a. The array should be sorted in ascending order.
Option B: b. The array should be sorted in descending order.
Option C: c. The array should have an even number of elements.
Option D: d. The array should have an odd number of elements.
Correct Option: a. The array should be sorted in ascending order.

Question: What is the time complexity of Binary Search in the worst-case scenario?
Option A: a. O(log log n)
Option B: b. O(log n)
Option C: c. O(n)
Correct Option: b. O(log n)

Question: Suppose we have an array of 10 elements, and we want to find an element using Binary Search. If the element is not present in the array, how many comparisons will the Binary Search algorithm make in the worst-case scenario?
Consider an array of 128 elements, and we want to find an element using Binary Search. What is the maximum number of comparisons required to find the element in the worst-case scenario?
What is the main concept of the Greedy Algorithm?
Option A: a. Divide and Conquer
Option B: b. Backtracking
Option C: c. Making the locally optimal choice
Option D: d. Dynamic Programming
Correct Option: c. Making the locally optimal choice

Question: Which of the following problems can be solved using the Greedy Algorithm?
Option A: a. Knapsack Problem
Option B: b. Traveling Salesman Problem
Option C: c. Binary Search
Option D: d. Sorting
Correct Option: a. Knapsack Problem
Subtopic Detail: Examples of problems that can be solved using Greedy Algorithm

Question: What is the key to ensuring the Greedy Algorithm yields an optimal solution?
Option A: a. Considering all possible solutions
Option B: b. Making the globally optimal choice
Option C: c. Choosing the locally optimal solution at each step
Option D: d. Using a recursive approach
Correct Option: c. Choosing the locally optimal solution at each step
Subtopic Detail: Optimal Substructure and Greedy Choice Property

Question: Consider a problem where you need to find the minimum number of coins to make a certain amount of money. A Greedy approach would involve:
Option A: a. Finding the minimum number of coins by recursively trying all possible combinations
Option B: b. Selecting the largest denomination of coin first
Option C: c. Considering the coin with the highest value-to-weight ratio first
Option D: d. Using a dynamic programming table to store intermediate results
Correct Option: b. Selecting the largest denomination of coin first
Subtopic Detail: Greedy approach to Coin Changing Problem

Question: Which of the following statements is true about the Greedy Algorithm?
Option A: a. It is guaranteed to find the global optimum for any problem
Option B: b. It can be used to solve any type of problem
Option C: c. It is not suitable for problems with overlapping subproblems
Option D: d. It may produce a suboptimal solution if the locally optimal choice is not globally optimal
Correct Option: d. It may produce a suboptimal solution if the locally optimal choice is not globally optimal
Subtopic Detail: Cases where Greedy Algorithm may fail

Question: What is the main idea behind Dynamic Programming?
Option A: a. To break down a problem into smaller subproblems and solve each only once.
Option B: b. To solve a problem using divide and conquer approach.
Option C: c. To use memoization to store the results of expensive function calls.
Option D: d. To use backtracking to find all possible solutions.
Correct Option: a. To break down a problem into smaller subproblems and solve each only once.

Question: What is memoization in Dynamic Programming?
Option A: a. A technique to memoize the results of expensive function calls to avoid recomputation.
Option B: b. A technique to solve a problem using a recursive approach.
Option C: c. A technique to break down a problem into smaller subproblems.
Option D: d. A technique to use backtracking to find all possible solutions.
Correct Option: a. A technique to memoize the results of expensive function calls to avoid recomputation.

Question: What is the time complexity of the Fibonacci series using Dynamic Programming?
Option B: b. O(n)
Option D: d. O(log n)
Correct Option: b. O(n)

Question: What is the difference between Top-Down and Bottom-Up approaches in Dynamic Programming?
Option A: a. Top-Down is a recursive approach, while Bottom-Up is an iterative approach.
Option B: b. Top-Down is an iterative approach, while Bottom-Up is a recursive approach.
Option C: c. Top-Down solves the problem by breaking it down into smaller subproblems, while Bottom-Up solves the problem by combining the solutions of smaller subproblems.
Option D: d. Top-Down solves the problem by combining the solutions of smaller subproblems, while Bottom-Up solves the problem by breaking it down into smaller subproblems.
Correct Option: a. Top-Down is a recursive approach, while Bottom-Up is an iterative approach.

Question: What is the optimal substructure property in Dynamic Programming?
Option A: a. The problem can be divided into smaller subproblems, and the optimal solution to the larger problem can be constructed from the optimal solutions of the subproblems.
Option B: b. The problem can be divided into smaller subproblems, and the optimal solution to the larger problem can be constructed from the approximate solutions of the subproblems.
Option C: c. The problem cannot be divided into smaller subproblems, and the optimal solution to the larger problem can be constructed from the optimal solutions of the subproblems.
Option D: d. The problem can be divided into smaller subproblems, and the optimal solution to the larger problem can be constructed from the heuristic solutions of the subproblems.
Correct Option: a. The problem can be divided into smaller subproblems, and the optimal solution to the larger problem can be constructed from the optimal solutions of the subproblems.

Question: What is the time complexity of the Breadth-First Search (BFS) algorithm?
Which graph traversal algorithm is guaranteed to find the shortest path from a source node to all other nodes in an unweighted graph?
Option A: a. Depth-First Search (DFS)
Option B: b. Breadth-First Search (BFS)
Option C: c. Dijkstra's algorithm
Option D: d. Bellman-Ford algorithm
Correct Option: b. Breadth-First Search (BFS)

Question: What is the main purpose of the Union function in the Kruskal's algorithm for finding the Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) of a graph?
Option A: a. To find the minimum edge weight in the graph
Option B: b. To merge two disjoint sets into a single set
Option C: c. To find the maximum flow in the graph
Option D: d. To topologically sort the vertices of the graph
Correct Option: b. To merge two disjoint sets into a single set

Question: Which of the following is a correct property of a Strongly Connected Component (SCC) in a directed graph?
Option A: a. It contains at least one cycle
Option B: b. It contains at most one cycle
Option C: c. It is a subgraph that has a path from every node to every other node
Option D: d. It is a directed acyclic graph
Correct Option: c. It is a subgraph that has a path from every node to every other node

Question: What is the purpose of the Low-Link values in the Tarjan's algorithm for finding Strongly Connected Components (SCCs) in a directed graph?
Option A: a. To keep track of the discovery time of each node
Option B: b. To keep track of the lowest link value reachable from each node
Option C: c. To keep track of the number of nodes in each SCC
Option D: d. To keep track of the maximum flow in the graph
Correct Option: b. To keep track of the lowest link value reachable from each node
